output:
Proof.
Assume that (∀ M1 ∈ ℝ, ∃ y > 0, ∀ x > y, f(x) > M1) (i).
Assume that (∀ M2 < 4, ∃ z > 0, ∀ x > z, g(x) > M2) (ii).
We need to show that (∃ c ∈ ℝ, f(c) + g(c) > 10).
Take M2 := (3).
* Indeed, (3 < 4).
* Use (ii) with M2 := (3) to choose z such that (z > 0) and (∀ x > z, g(x) > 3).
We need to show that (∃ c ∈ ℝ, f(c) + g(c) > 10) remains valid.
Take M1 := (7).
- Indeed, (7 ∈ ℝ).
- Use (i) with M1 := (7) to choose y such that (y > 0) and (∀ x > y, f(x) > 7).
We need to show that (∃ c ∈ ℝ, f(c) + g(c) > 10) by choosing an appropriate c.
Choose c := (max(y, z) + 1).
* We have that (c > y) and (c > z).
* Hence, from (∀ x > y, f(x) > 7) it follows that (f(c) > 7).
* And from (∀ x > z, g(x) > 3) it follows that (g(c) > 3).
It holds that (7 + 3 = 10) and therefore (f(c) + g(c) > 10).
We conclude that (∃ c ∈ ℝ, f(c) + g(c) > 10).
Qed.
